text: why do I write I I write for several
reasons probably foremost of which is
it's the only thing I can do to to be
honest I I say that because I have
friends who I believe are cursed by
being multi-talented um and I do feel
like that is a curse um or if you're not
cursed by being multi-talented I know
people who are cursed by having many
different interests
um so they their attention is kind of
fragmented across many fields and I
think it's difficult when you're like
that unless you're truly a Renaissance
person and you can kind of handle all of
it at once I think it's hard to to sort
of find your way and you know I just
never was interested in anything else I
was never particularly good at anything
else there was there's never been
anything else that I wanted or craved or
loved as much as this work um so in that
one way I would say that my life has
been phenomenally simple um I've managed
to complicate my life in all sorts of
other ways um but but just this was a
kind of I don't know I think in in
everybody's life there's one thing that
you get handed as a simple gift and um
and for me it was this this whole idea
of
writing I follow my curiosity I suppose
that's where most people's creative
processes begin unless um they're sort
of more analytical and intellectual
about it and they actually set out to
conquer or understand something which
isn't necessarily how I work um I I
always feel like it's a tap on the
shoulder that begins it you know um and
it's it's not necessarily a passionate
response at the beginning it's curiosity
is the best word for it because you you
feel this little tap and then um it just
pulls your attention for a minute and
you just think well that's funny why did
I get that response why am I interested
in Lobster fisherman um you know why do
I why does that tweak something in me
and then you sort of sniff it out and um
and for me
um I'm not a particularly imaginative
person I have a sister um Katherine
Murdoch who's also a writer and she's
really a fabulist even when we were
growing up she was kind of like Shahara
zad you know she can just invent things
and make up worlds and I've never been
that kind of person my interest is is
much more about reflecting on the world
as it is um even when I was writing
fiction I felt like I had to kind of go
to the places that I was writing about
and roll around in them for a while and
and you know just really commune with
the people there and like taste the soil
you know and and learn about it and so
my creative process is really it's
really involving you know it's really
about a kind of all over s sensory
experience and um and I can't begin to
write something until I feel like I've
become a bit of an expert on it um so
the writing comes last and and it's all
this buildup all this research all this
thinking all this contemplation all this
experimentation and then once I've got
this Collective of ideas and information
and notes I can sit down and at that
point it starts to feel like I'm an
archaeologist and that underneath all
those notes there's an ancient city and
I just have to kind of dust it and find
it and piece it together and put the
pieces of pottery in shards and kind of
recreate it um in some strange and kind
of indescribable way
